24.text: The  Kalgoorlie  Terrane  lies  in  the  southern  section  of  the  Norseman  –Wiluna  Greenstone

25.text: Belt. The terrane encompasses a suite of granitic and greenstone units separated from adjacent

26.text: terranes  by  either  granitic  intrusions  or  major  faults.  The  Mt  Monger  Fault  forms  the  eastern

27.text: margin,  whereas  the  western  margin  is  bounded  by  the  regionally  extensive  Ida  Fault.

28.text: Ultramafic-hosted  syngenetic  nickel  sulphide  deposits  are  common  throughout  the  Kalgoorlie

29.text: Terrane, with the greatest concentrations observed at Kambalda. Epigenetic gold mineralisation

text:
The  Kalgoorlie  Terrane  lies  in  the  southern  section  of  the  Norseman  –Wiluna  Greenstone 
 Belt. The terrane encompasses a suite of granitic and greenstone units separated from adjacent 
 terranes  by  either  granitic  intrusions  or  major  faults.  The  Mt  Monger  Fault  forms  the  eastern 
 margin,  whereas  the  western  margin  is  bounded  by  the  regionally  extensive  Ida  Fault. 
 Ultramafic-hosted  syngenetic  nickel  sulphide  deposits  are  common  throughout  the  Kalgoorlie 
 Terrane, with the greatest concentrations observed at Kambalda. Epigenetic gold mineralisation

8.text: Eastern  Goldfields  Superterrane  comprises  approximately  northnorthwest-  trending,  linear

9.text: greenstone  belts  of  metamorphosed  felsic,  mafic  and  ultramafic  volcanic  and  intrusive  rocks,

10.text: together with associated epiclastic, including volcaniclastic sedimentary rocks (Trofimovs, et. al,

11.text: 2006). The greenstone succession was emplaced primarily between 2720 and 2655 Ma . Granitic

12.text: intrusion  coincided  with  the  later  stages  of  greenstone  formation,  with  a  period  of  high-Ca

 greenstone  belts  of  metamorphosed  felsic,  mafic  and  ultramafic  volcanic  and  intrusive  rocks, 
 together with associated epiclastic, including volcaniclastic sedimentary rocks (Trofimovs, et. al, 
 2006). The greenstone succession was emplaced primarily between 2720 and 2655 Ma . Granitic 
 intrusion  coincided  with  the  later  stages  of  greenstone  formation,  with  a  period  of  high-Ca

17.text: between 2708 and 2665 Ma for the sequence. The domain has undergone two main phases of

18.text: deformation.  Initial  south-over-north  thrust  faulting  repeated  and  thickened  the  stratigraphy

19.text: between  2683  and  2672  Ma,  and  subsequent  east-northeast  –  west-southwest  shortening

20.text: produced macroscale folding, interpreted to post-date 2655 Ma.

22.text: The Bardoc Tectonic Zone trends NNW, parallel to bedding in the western limb of the Scotia

23.text: antiform,  the  dominant  structure  within  the  Boorara  Domain.  This  regionally  extensive  D2

24.text: structure is a broad, open fold that plunges moderately to the southeast. Local younging criteria

25.text: indicate  that  the  antiform  is  an  upward  facing  anticline.  The  Scotia–Kanowna  granodiorite

26.text: batholith  lies  within  the  center  of  the  Scotia  anticline.  Basalt  and  komatiite,  with  associated

27.text: dolerite  and  subordinate  felsic  volcaniclastic  sedimentary  rock,  dominate  the  structurally

28.text: disrupted  stratigraphy  in  the  northern  part  of  the  domain,  whereas  towards  the  south,  the

29.text: succession predominantly comprises felsic volcaniclastic siltstone, sandstone and conglomerate

30.text: with subordinate carbonaceous shale, chert and felsic volcanic rock intercalations. Interlayered

31.text: horizons of komatiite and basalt in the southern half of the Boorara Domain are interpreted to be

32.text: thrust  repetitions  of  the  northern  strata.  Two  major  compressional  orogenies  affecting  the

text:
between 2708 and 2665 Ma for the sequence. The domain has undergone two main phases of 
 deformation.  Initial  south-over-north  thrust  faulting  repeated  and  thickened  the  stratigraphy 
 between  2683  and  2672  Ma,  and  subsequent  east-northeast  –  west-southwest  shortening 
 produced macroscale folding, interpreted to post-date 2655 Ma. 
 The Bardoc Tectonic Zone trends NNW, parallel to bedding in the western limb of the Scotia 
 antiform,  the  dominant  structure  within  the  Boorara  Domain.  This  regionally  extensive  D2 
 structure is a broad, open fold that plunges moderately to the southeast. Local younging criteria 
 indicate  that  the  antiform  is  an  upward  facing  anticline.  The  Scotia–Kanowna  granodiorite 
 batholith  lies  within  the  center  of  the  Scotia  anticline.  Basalt  and  komatiite,  with  associated 
 dolerite  and  subordinate  felsic  volcaniclastic  sedimentary  rock,  dominate  the  structurally 
 disrupted  stratigraphy  in  the  northern  part  of  the  domain,  whereas  towards  the  south,  the 
 succession predominantly comprises felsic volcaniclastic siltstone, sandstone and conglomerate 
 with subordinate carbonaceous shale, chert and felsic volcanic rock intercalations. Interlayered 
 horizons of komatiite and basalt in the southern half of the Boorara Domain are interpreted to be 
 thrust  repetitions  of  the  northern  strata.  Two  major  compressional  orogenies  affecting  the

13.text: monzogranite.  The  Claypan  Dam  project  overlies  the  felsic  volcanics,  mafics  and  ultramafics

16.text: Major gold deposits associated with the Boorara and Kanowna Shears include the Paddington

17.text: and Kanowna Belle mines respectively. Known gold mineralisation in the vicinity of the project

18.text: area has been found to be associated with quartz veining in narrow steeply east dipping north

19.text: north west trending shear zones cutting through mafic volcanics and in places felsic intrusives.

text:
and sedimentary rocks.  
 Scotia-Kanowna  Anticline.    The  core  of  the  Scotia-Kanowna  anticline  is  occupied  by 
 monzogranite.  The  Claypan  Dam  project  overlies  the  felsic  volcanics,  mafics  and  ultramafics 
 which are wrapped around the nose of the anticline (Figure 5). 
 Major gold deposits associated with the Boorara and Kanowna Shears include the Paddington 
 and Kanowna Belle mines respectively. Known gold mineralisation in the vicinity of the project 
 area has been found to be associated with quartz veining in narrow steeply east dipping north 
 north west trending shear zones cutting through mafic volcanics and in places felsic intrusives.

16.text: The geology of the area has been described as follows. “The Boulder- Lefroy fault passes

17.text: through  the  area.  The  basement  geology  consists  of  a  layered  and  folded  sequence  of

18.text: sedimentary  rocks,  mafic  and  ultramafic  extrusive  rocks,  mafic  intrusive  rocks  and  felsic

19.text: volcanics trending northwest-southeast. The stratigraphy is displaced by a north-south trending

20.text: fault.  The  project  area  is  covered  by  alluvium  and  sandy  lake  deposits.  There  are  isolated

21.text: outcrops of high-Mg basalt and greywacke in the east and conglomerate and rhyolite in the west.

22.text: Folding and faulting trends northwest – southeast in the project area” (I13426, A573335).

26.text: The extreme south eastern corner of AMX’s ‘Golden Cities’ project covered Jackson Gold

27.text: tenement P24/3936. Exploration during the period 1997 to 2000 included auger, RAB, aircore,

28.text: RC, diamond drilling, petrography and mineral resource estimation (a55974, a58982). This work

29.text: was  concentrated  on  the  numerous  gold  prospects  included  in  the  project  area  (Havana  Suva,

30.text: Jakarta,  London,  Lisbon,  Oriental  etc.)  and  no  exploration  was  conducted  in  the  area  now

text:
The geology of the area has been described as follows. “The Boulder- Lefroy fault passes 
 through  the  area.  The  basement  geology  consists  of  a  layered  and  folded  sequence  of 
 sedimentary  rocks,  mafic  and  ultramafic  extrusive  rocks,  mafic  intrusive  rocks  and  felsic 
 volcanics trending northwest-southeast. The stratigraphy is displaced by a north-south trending 
 fault.  The  project  area  is  covered  by  alluvium  and  sandy  lake  deposits.  There  are  isolated 
 outcrops of high-Mg basalt and greywacke in the east and conglomerate and rhyolite in the west. 
 Folding and faulting trends northwest – southeast in the project area” (I13426, A573335). 
 AMX Resources NL (Item 12633) 
 The extreme south eastern corner of AMX’s ‘Golden Cities’ project covered Jackson Gold 
 tenement P24/3936. Exploration during the period 1997 to 2000 included auger, RAB, aircore, 
 RC, diamond drilling, petrography and mineral resource estimation (a55974, a58982). This work 
 was  concentrated  on  the  numerous  gold  prospects  included  in  the  project  area  (Havana  Suva, 
 Jakarta,  London,  Lisbon,  Oriental  etc.)  and  no  exploration  was  conducted  in  the  area  now 
 covered by P24/3936.
